questions.text: 'a' wave in JVP corresponds to?
questions.solution:
The "a" wave in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is a positive wave, which corresponds to right atrial contraction.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: The c wave seen in a normal JVP waveform represents?

choices.text: Bulging of tricuspid valve into the right atrium
Venous filling of the right atrium
Emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle

questions.solution:
The c-wave in a JVP waveform represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.

JVP measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

questions.text: The following abnormality on a JVP waveform can be seen in which of the given conditions?
questions.solution:
The given waveform shows a cannon ‘a’ wave seen in ventricular tachycardia. It occurs since atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve in ventricular tachycardia.

JVP measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure.

Note: Giant/prominent a-waves occur during every beat while cannon a-waves result from arrhythmias, therefore, are usually intermittent. The ECG is helpful to look for rhythm disturbances that are associated with cannon a-waves whereas echocardiography can be used to assess structural defects (of right atrium) that are associated with giant a-waves.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with complaints of weakness, restlessness, and chest pain. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg, his heart sounds are muffled, and his neck veins are distended. What is the typical JVP finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention (Beck’s triad) are the three principal features of cardiac tamponade. The typical JVP finding here is absent y-descent.

JVP shows a prominent x (early systolic) descent and an absent y (early diastolic) descent because of the ventricle's limited or absent early diastolic filling. JVP is almost always elevated in cardiac tamponade and may be associated with venous distention in the forehead and scalp.

There may be reductions in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves in cardiac tamponade.

Note: Alternation of QRS complexes, usually in a 2:1 ratio, on ECG is called electrical alternans. It is caused by the movement of the heart in the pericardial space. Electrical alternans is also seen in patients with myocardial ischemia, acute pulmonary embolism, and tachyarrhythmias.

questions.text: Deep y descent in JVP is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
The y-descent in jugular venous pulse (JVP) corresponds to the fall in right atrial pressure after the tricuspid valve opening in the early diastolic phase of the right ventricle. Y-descent is attenuated or absent in cardiac tamponade because of resistance to ventricular filling in the early diastole.

Other options:

Options B and C: Restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis can have deep y descent due to rapid filling of the right ventricle during early diastole.

Option D: In patients with tricuspid regurgitation, increased blood flow to the right atria through the incompetent tricuspid valve during ventricular systole results in a prominent v wave. When the tricuspid valve opens during ventricular diastole, this increased blood in the right atria enters rapidly into the right ventricle during early diastole resulting in deep y-descent.

questions.text:
The following four patients were examined on a tilt table for postural hypotension. The blood pressures before and immediately after performing head-up tilt are given below. Choose the correct option regarding the patients who suffer from orthostatic hypotension.
  Before head-up tilt After head-up tilt
SBP (mmHg) DBP (mmHg) SBP (mmHg) DBP (mmHg)
Patient 1 140 90 126 76
Patient 2 132 84 110 80
Patient 3 126 78 108 70
Patient 4 136 88 114 82
questions.solution:
Orthostatic hypotension is defined as a reduction in systolic blood pressure of at least 20 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure of at least 10 mmHg within 3 min of standing or head-up tilt on a tilt table.

On standing, blood is displaced to the lower extremities, causing a drop in the venous return to the heart. This drop leads to a decrease in cardiac output and stimulation of compensatory mechanisms which trigger a reflex increase in sympathetic (vasoconstrictor) outflow. Orthostatic hypotension is a manifestation of sympathetic (autonomic) failure. 

Symptoms include light-headedness, dizziness, and presyncope (near-faintness) in response to sudden postural change.

questions.text: Pulsus paradoxus is seen in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Pulsus bisferiens is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, not pulsus paradoxus.

Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic pressure by > 10 mmHg with inspiration. It is an exaggeration of the normal response. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Hemorrhagic shock
  • Obstructive lung disease
  • Tension pneumothorax

questions.text: Pulsus bisferiens is seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Pulsus alternans (characterized by alternating strong and weak beats) is seen in left ventricular dysfunction. 

Pulsus bisferiens is a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Advanced aortic regurgitation (AR)
  • Aortic stenosis (AS) with AR
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan’s pulse, is characterized by a sharp rise and a rapid fall-off and is seen in aortic regurgitation (AR) due to the fact that arterial pressure falls rapidly in late systole and early diastole.

In AR, the pulse pressure is widened due to systolic hypertension and decreased diastolic pressure. The diastolic pressure is measured at Korotkoff phase IV. In certain patients with AR or a combination of aortic stenosis (AS) and AR, the carotid arterial pulse may exhibit a bisferiens pattern, characterized by two systolic waves separated by a trough.

The apical impulse is heaving and displaced inferiorly. A diastolic thrill may be palpable along the left sternal border. 

A2 is usually absent in AR. An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic AR. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge.

Severe AS (Option A) would show pulsus parvus et tardus, characterized by the carotid pulse rising slowly to a delayed peak. 

Chronic mitral regurgitation (Option D) shows a sharp, low volume upstroke due to reduced cardiac output and acute mitral regurgitation demonstrates narrow pulse pressure. 

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

Durozeiz’s sign

questions.text: A loud S1 is associated with?
questions.solution:
Rheumatic mitral stenosis is associated with loud S1.

The greater the distance the valve travels to close, the louder is the sound. Increased left atrial pressures in rheumatic mitral stenosis force the mobile portion of the mitral valve leaflets far apart such that they are forced closed from a relatively far distance, resulting in a loud S1. In calcific mitral stenosis, leaflet mobility is poor, and they are not separated by a large distance, resulting in a soft S1.

Loud S1 is heard in the following:

  • Short PR intervals
  • Early stages of mitral stenosis as long as the valves are pliable
  • Atrial myxoma
  • High output states
  • Tachycardia

Soft S1 is heard in the following:

  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Long PR intervals
  • Calcified Mitral stenosis
  • Left ventricular contractile dysfunction
  • Beta-receptor blockers
  • Pericardial effusion, obesity, COPD- due to decreased conduction through the chest wall

questions.text: A hypertensive patient presented with chest pain and was found to have dilated cardiomyopathy on an echocardiogram. On auscultation, a reversed splitting of second heart sound was heard. Which of the following could most likely be responsible for the same?
questions.solution:
Reversed (or paradoxical) splitting refers to the situation when P2 is heard before A2. This is seen in the following:

  • LBBB
  • HOCM
  • Right ventricular pacing
  • Severe AS
  • Acute myocardial ischemia

questions.text: Disappearance of loud S1 in mitral stenosis occurs in all except:
questions.solution:
Loud S1 is heard in mild mitral stenosis (MS).

The intensity of S1 depends on the distance over which the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve moves, leaflet mobility, LV contractility, and PR interval. It is independent of the severity of MS.

Loud S1 is seen in early rheumatic MS, short PR interval, and hyperdynamic circulatory states.

S1 becomes soft in case of calcified leaflets, long PR interval, associated aortic regurgitation and LV dysfunction.

questions.text: While examining a patient, you hear a widely split S2 on auscultation. Which of the following is not a possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A wide split of S2 is not seen in the left bundle branch block (LBBB), however paradoxical splitting is seen.

S2 is normally heard as A2-P2. This split is exaggerated in conditions that cause early aortic valve closure or delayed pulmonary valve closure.

Option A: In atrial septal defect (ASD), left ventricle (LV) ejection time decreases due to the shunting of the blood from the left atrium (LA) to the right atrium leading to early aortic valve closure.

Option B: In mitral regurgitation (MR), due to the regurgitation of blood from the LV to the LA, the LV ejection time decreases leading to early aortic valve closure.

Option C: In pulmonary stenosis (PS), the delayed closure of pulmonary valves leads to the splitting of S2.

Wide splitting of S2 is also heard in RBBB and LV pacing.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a fixed wide splitting of S2?
questions.solution:
Fixed wide splitting of S2 is seen in atrial septal defect (ASD).

The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: S3 and S4 are high pitched systolic sounds
S4 is heard during the ventricular-filling phase
S3 occurs due to rapid filling of the ventricles during atrial systole

questions.solution:
S4 is heard during the ventricular-filling phase.

S3 and S4 are diastolic sounds that are low pitched, and best heard with the bell of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex in the left lateral decubitus position.

 S3 - Ventricular gallop  S4 - Atrial gallop


 Occurs during early ventricular diastole

Occurs near the end of ventricular diastole

During the first rapid ventricular filling

  During active ventricular filling       (filling by atrial contraction)

Due to a sudden rush of blood entering a volume-depleted ventricle (normal ventricular compliance)

Due to vibration of the ventricular wall during atrial contraction because of increased stiffness of ventricular walls (decreased ventricular compliance)
It can be physiological in children and young adults. Always pathological
In older patients, it indicates systolic heart failure Indicates diastolic heart failure

The presence of an S3 and S4 heart sound is called a summation gallop and sounds like a galloping horse.

questions.text: An ECG of a patient who underwent pulmonary artery catheterization showed a right bundle branch block. On auscultation, a widely split S1 was observed. Which of the following is true regarding this auscultatory finding?

choices.text: The split remains constant with inspiration and expiration
The change in split depends on the degree of bundle branch block

questions.solution:
In a patient with a right bundle branch block (RBBB), there's a widely split S1 which increases with inspiration.

S1 is normally heard as a single sound. Any delay in the closure of the tricuspid valve or early closure of the mitral valve produces a split in S1. During inspiration, venous return to the right atrium increases. Therefore, the atria take a longer time to empty into the ventricles delaying the closure of the tricuspid valve. This increases the split in S1 during inspiration. In a patient with an RBBB, the tricuspid valve closure is further delayed leading to a wide split in S1.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a history of occasional palpitations. She has no history of chest pain or dyspnea. On examination, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, the pulse is 82/min and regular. Joint hypermobility and thoracolumbar scoliosis are present. Gorlin's sign is positive. On auscultation, a click is heard after S1, followed by a late systolic murmur.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis of the above scenario is Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS).

EDS is a group of clinically and genetically heterogeneous connective tissue disorders. Typical presenting features include joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility. EDS type 6 is also characterized by scoliosis. Gorlin’s sign refers to the ability of patients of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue.

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is a frequent finding in patients with EDS. An early systolic click which may be followed by a late systolic murmur is the auscultatory finding heard in MVP.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diastolic sound?
questions.solution:
The ejection click is a systolic sound. 

Ejection clicks are high-pitched sounds that occur at the moment of the maximal opening of the aortic or pulmonary valves. They are heard just after the first heart sound.

Ejection clicks occur in:

  • Non-calcific aortic or pulmonary stenosis
  • Aortic or pulmonary root dilatation 
  • Congenital bicuspid aortic or pulmonary valves

Nonejection clicks, which occur after the onset of the carotid upstroke, are related to the mitral valve prolapse.

questions.text: On auscultation of a patient, you hear a murmur between S1 and S2. Which of the following conditions is not likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
A murmur occurring between S1 and S2 is a systolic murmur. Pulmonary regurgitation produces a diastolic murmur.

The causes of systolic murmurs are as follows:

  • Mid-systolic- aortic stenosis, pulmonic stenosis, ASD, HOCM.
  • Holosystolic/pansystolic- mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, VSD.
  • Late systolic- mitral valve prolapse.

The causes of diastolic murmurs are as follows:

  • Early diastolic- aortic regurgitation, pulmonic regurgitation.
  • Mid/late diastolic- mitral stenosis, tricuspid stenosis, Austin-Flint.

The causes of continuous murmurs are as follows:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (machinery or Gibson's murmur).
  • Venous hum
  • AV fistula
  • Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm

questions.text: While examining a patient, you hear a mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation on auscultation of the precordium. Which of the following condition is associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
A mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation and an opening snap is typically seen in mitral stenosis.

The presystolic accentuation is due to the atrial contraction forcing blood through the stenosed mitral valve. The presystolic accentuation disappears in atrial fibrillation.

Option A: Mitral regurgitation presents with a holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex with radiation to the left axilla.

Option B: Mitral valve prolapse presents with an early systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur is heard.

Option C: Aortic stenosis presents with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo ejection systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border, with radiation of the murmur to the carotid arteries.

questions.text: You are a part of a health camp conducting check-ups for cardiovascular ailments. On auscultation of a patient's precordial area, you hear a systolic murmur. On asking the patient to perform the following maneuver, the intensity of the murmur increased. Which of the following conditions is associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the Valsalva maneuver. The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) increases in intensity while performing the Valsalva maneuver.

The murmurs produced by TR (tricuspid regurgitation), AS (aortic stenosis), and MR (mitral regurgitation) decrease in intensity while performing the Valsalva maneuver.

Note: Valsalva maneuver decreases the intensity of all murmurs except MVP (mitral valve prolapse) and HCM.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur

questions.text: While auscultating a patient's precordium, a murmur was heard that decreased in intensity on performing the following sustained maneuver. Which of the given condition is associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a sustained handgrip maneuver. The murmur of aortic stenosis decreases in intensity during sustained handgrip.

Maneuvers like sustained handgrip, simultaneous inflation of blood pressure cuffs above the systolic in both upper limbs, and infusion of vasopressors increase the systemic vascular resistance (afterload). Since increasing afterload will prevent blood from flowing in a normal forward path, it will increase any murmurs that are due to backward flowing blood and decresase the ones due to forward blood flow.

Murmurs that increase in intensity on sustained handgrip:

  • Mitral regurgitation
  • Ventricular septal defect
  • Aortic regurgitation

Murmurs that decrease in intensity on sustained handgrip:

  • Aortic stenosis
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing?
questions.solution:
The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) increases with standing, as there is a reduction in preload. In conditions of reduced preload, there is lesser end diastolic volume in the left ventricle, leading to a narrower outflow tract, and a louder murmur is heard.

The murmur heard in HOCM is a mid-systolic murmur, which is loudest along the left sternal border. It increases in conditions of decreased preload and afterload (standing, valsalva, vagal maneuvers) or conditions of increased contractility (inotropic stimulation) and decreases when preload and afterload are increased (squatting, vasopressors).

Most murmurs decrease in intensity with reduced preload and afterload except HOCM and mitral valve prolapse (MVP).

questions.text: A child was being evaluated for an underlying cardiac defect. On auscultation, a murmur was heard which began in systole, enveloped the second heart sound, and continued through some portion of the diastole. Which of the following condition is not associated with this finding?

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation

questions.solution:
The murmur described above is a continuous murmur.

A continuous murmur is produced when there is a pressure gradient between the cardiac chambers or the blood vessels throughout the systole and diastole. Continous murmurs are characterised by the flow of blood in the same direction and through the same channel during systole and diastole. These murmurs begin in systole, envelope the second heart sound (S2), and continue through some portion of diastole.

Conditions producing a continuous murmur:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Venous hum
  • AV fistula
  • Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm

Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation does not produce a continuous murmur. It produces a systolic-diastolic murmur as the blood flows through different channels during systole and diastole. These murmurs do not envelope S2.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Gallavardin effect?

choices.text: It is associated with a diastolic murmur
It is seen in aortic stenosis
It refers to the radiation of murmur to the carotids
The transmission makes the murmur low pitched

questions.solution: The Gallavardin effect refers to the phenomenon of the transmission of the mid-systolic murmur of aortic stenosis to the apex where it becomes higher pitched.

questions.text: A patient presents with easy fatiguability and shortness of breath on moderate physical activity. On auscultation, a holosystolic murmur is heard over the lower left sternal border and radiating to the epigastrium. Which of the following condition is most likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
A holosystolic murmur that is best heard over the lower left sternal border and radiating to the epigastrium most likely arises from tricuspid regurgitation.

Related Pearl: The causes of holosystolic murmur are:

  1. Mitral regurgitation

  • Best heard at the apex
  • Radiates to axilla or base
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • A2 is not heard at the apex

  2. Tricuspid regurgitation

  • Best heard at lower left sternal border
  • Radiates to the epigastrium and right sternal border
  • Increases in intensity during inspiration
  • Prominent c-v waves seen in JVP

  3. Ventricular septal defect

  • Beat heard over left 3rd and 4th intercostal space
  • Radiates widely
  • Palpable thrill present
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • Wide splitting of S2 seen

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Stills murmur?

choices.text: It is heard in mitral regurgitation
It is best heard in left lateral decubitus position

questions.solution:
Still’s murmur refers to the benign grade 2 mid-systolic murmur heard at mid or lower left sternal border in normal children and adolescents. Louder in hyperdynamic states(fever, anxiety).

The anatomic basis for the murmur has not been definitively determined. It is best heard in a supine position.

questions.text: Graham Steell murmur is heard in?
questions.solution:
Graham Steell murmur is the early to mid-diastolic murmur heard in pulmonary regurgitation.

It is best heard in 2nd left intercostal space and radiates along left sternal border. It can increase with inspiration.

questions.text: Carey Coombs murmur is heard in?
questions.solution:
Carey Coombs murmur is heard in mitral valvulitis.

It is a mid-diastolic murmur heard during an episode of acute rheumatic fever causing mitral valvulitis.

It is produced due to the flow of blood through an edematous mitral valve and dissipates with the resolution of the acute attack.

questions.text: Austin-Flint murmur is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Austin-Flint murmur is a low-pitched mid to late diastolic murmur of chronic severe AR.

It results from the turbulence at the mitral inflow area from the mixture of regurgitant and forward blood flow. It is best heard at the apex.

Austin-Flint murmur is often confused with the murmur of mitral stenosis. This can be differentiated based on the following:

Features Chronic AR MS
Opening snap Absent Present

Effect of vasodilator administration

Murmur becomes shorter and softer.

Mechanism- Fall in the diastolic pressure gradient between the aorta and left ventricle.

Murmur remains constant or increases in intensity.

Mechanism- Reflex increase in cardiac output and mitral valve flow.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario?

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of transient loss of consciousness in this patient is suggestive of syncope. Hence, an ECG must be done to rule out cardiac causes for syncope like - arrhythmias (atrial fibrillation, sinus node dysfunction, supra ventricular tachycardias) or a structural cardiac abnormality.

A CT would only be required if a seizure or transient ischemic attack (TIA) is suspected. However, in this case - the episode only lasted for a few seconds, the patient has no history of similar episodes in the past and there are no lasting neurological deficits after the episode. Therefore, option B is incorrect.  

Syncope is a transient loss of consciousness caused by global cerebral hypoperfusion. It can be due to multiple causes, but is broadly divided into - neurally mediated syncope, orthostatic hypotension and cardiac syncope. 

The initial workup for a case of syncope includes: 

  1. Detailed history of the episode and past history of similar episodes 
  2. Physical examination mainly to check BP in standing and supine positions to
  3. rule out orthostatic hypotension.
  4. A resting ECG to look for cardiac arrhythmia
  5. Option B: If the ECG is normal, no further tests are needed. If the ECG is suggestive of cardiac arrhythmia, then further tests including continuous ECG monitoring and electrophysiological studies may be done.

Option C: Tilt-table testing is done in patients with recurrent syncopal attacks who are suspected to have vasovagal syncope. Psychiatric evaluation is done in patients with recurrent unexplained syncopal attacks.

Option D: Vestibular neuritis is associated with vertigo, where the patients typically complain of dizziness and a sense of spinning of the head.
